modules.title: API Basics & HTTP Fundamentals
modules.description: Learn what APIs are, how HTTP powers them, and why documentation matters.

lessons.title: Understanding APIs: The Restaurant Analogy
learning_objectives: Explain what an API is using real-world analogies
Understand the client-server model
Recognize why API documentation is critical
Identify the role of a documentation writer
lessons.contentHtml:
What Is an API?

Welcome! Before we write a single word of documentation, we need to deeply understand what we're documenting.

The most common analogy for an API (Application Programming Interface) is a waiter at a restaurant:

  • You (the client) are a customer sitting at a table
  • The kitchen (the server) has all the food (the data)
  • The API is the waiter who takes your request and brings back the response
üí° Pro Tip: Think of API documentation as the menu. Without a menu, customers don't know what to order. A bad menu causes confusion; a great menu ensures a smooth experience.

The Client-Server Model

An API enables communication in a client-server model:

Client  ‚îÄ‚îÄrequest‚îÄ‚îÄ>  Server
        <‚îÄ‚îÄresponse‚îÄ‚îÄ
  • Client: The application requesting data (mobile app, website, script)
  • Server: The system that processes requests and returns data
  • API: The interface that defines how they communicate

Why API Documentation Matters

API documentation is the bridge between the server's capabilities and the developer's understanding. Poor docs lead to:

  • ‚ùå Developer frustration
  • ‚ùå Support tickets flooding your team
  • ‚ùå Slow adoption of your API
  • ‚ùå Integration errors

Great documentation leads to:

  • ‚úÖ Fast developer onboarding
  • ‚úÖ Reduced support burden
  • ‚úÖ Higher API adoption
  • ‚úÖ Happy developers = successful product
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't assume developers will "figure it out." If it's not documented, it doesn't exist.

Your Role as a Documentation Writer

You are not just passively listing features‚Äîyou are actively guiding developers to successful outcomes. Think of yourself as:

  • A teacher (educating about the API)
  • A guide (showing the best path forward)
  • A translator (converting technical specs into clear instructions)
üß† Quick Recap:
  • APIs enable client-server communication
  • Documentation is the "menu" that guides developers
  • Good docs = happy developers = successful API
  • Your job: guide, teach, and translate

lessons.title: HTTP Methods: The Verbs of the Web
learning_objectives: Master the 5 core HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE)
Identify idempotent vs. non-idempotent operations
Understand safe vs. unsafe methods
Document HTTP methods correctly in API docs
lessons.contentHtml:
HTTP Methods: The Core Verbs

HTTP methods (also called verbs) define the type of action to perform on a resource. Think of them as the commands you give to the server.

The 5 Essential HTTP Methods

1. GET ‚Äî Retrieve Data

Purpose: Request data from the server without modifying anything.

  • ‚úÖ Safe: Does not change server state
  • ‚úÖ Idempotent: Multiple identical requests have the same effect
  • üìñ Documentation Example: "Retrieves a list of all videos in the collection"

2. POST ‚Äî Create New Resources

Purpose: Submit data to create a new resource.

  • ‚ùå Not safe: Changes server state
  • ‚ùå Not idempotent: Each request creates a new resource
  • üìñ Documentation Example: "Creates a new video upload"

3. PUT ‚Äî Replace/Update Resources

Purpose: Replace an entire resource with new data.

  • ‚ùå Not safe: Changes server state
  • ‚úÖ Idempotent: Sending the same PUT request multiple times has the same result
  • üìñ Documentation Example: "Updates the entire video metadata"

4. PATCH ‚Äî Partial Updates

Purpose: Update only specific fields of a resource.

  • ‚ùå Not safe: Changes server state
  • ‚úÖ Often idempotent (depends on implementation)
  • üìñ Documentation Example: "Updates the video title and description"

5. DELETE ‚Äî Remove Resources

Purpose: Delete a resource from the server.

  • ‚ùå Not safe: Changes server state
  • ‚úÖ Idempotent: Deleting the same resource multiple times has the same effect
  • üìñ Documentation Example: "Permanently deletes a video"
üí° Pro Tip: Always document which HTTP method to use for each endpoint. Developers need to know whether they're creating (POST) or updating (PUT/PATCH).

Idempotency: Why It Matters

An idempotent operation produces the same result no matter how many times you perform it.

MethodIdempotent?Why?
GET‚úÖ YesReading data doesn't change anything
POST‚ùå NoEach request creates a new resource
PUT‚úÖ YesReplacing the same resource yields the same result
PATCH‚ö†Ô∏è MaybeDepends on how it's implemented
DELETE‚úÖ YesDeleting an already-deleted resource is still "deleted"
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't use GET for operations that modify data (e.g., deleting a record). Use the correct HTTP method for semantic clarity.
üß† Quick Recap:
  • GET = Read, POST = Create, PUT = Replace, PATCH = Update, DELETE = Remove
  • Idempotent methods: GET, PUT, DELETE (usually PATCH)
  • Always document the correct HTTP method for each endpoint

quiz.question: Which HTTP method is idempotent?
quiz.explanation: PUT is idempotent because replacing the same resource multiple times yields the same result. POST creates a new resource each time, so it's not idempotent.

quiz.question: You want to update only the title of a video. Which method is most appropriate?
quiz.explanation: PATCH is used for partial updates. PUT would require sending the entire resource data.

quiz.question: What HTTP status code indicates successful resource creation?
quiz.explanation: 201 Created indicates that a new resource was successfully created via POST.

lessons.title: HTTP Status Codes: Understanding Server Responses
learning_objectives: Categorize HTTP status codes by class (2xx, 3xx, 4xx, 5xx)
Identify the most common status codes
Document error responses effectively
Write helpful error messages in API docs
lessons.contentHtml:
HTTP Status Codes: The Server's Response Language

Every HTTP response includes a status code that tells the client what happened. Understanding these codes is essential for writing clear error documentation.

Status Code Classes

2xx ‚Äî Success ‚úÖ

  • 200 OK: Request succeeded, data returned
  • 201 Created: Resource successfully created (POST)
  • 204 No Content: Success, but no data to return (DELETE)

3xx ‚Äî Redirection ‚Ü©Ô∏è

  • 301 Moved Permanently: Resource has a new permanent URL
  • 302 Found: Temporary redirect
  • 304 Not Modified: Cached version is still valid

4xx ‚Äî Client Errors ‚ùå

These indicate the client did something wrong.

  • 400 Bad Request: Malformed request syntax
  • 401 Unauthorized: Missing or invalid authentication
  • 403 Forbidden: Authenticated but not authorized
  • 404 Not Found: Resource doesn't exist
  • 422 Unprocessable Entity: Valid syntax, but semantic errors (e.g., invalid field values)
  • 429 Too Many Requests: Rate limit exceeded

5xx ‚Äî Server Errors üî•

These indicate the server failed to fulfill a valid request.

  • 500 Internal Server Error: Generic server failure
  • 502 Bad Gateway: Invalid response from upstream server
  • 503 Service Unavailable: Server temporarily down
  • 504 Gateway Timeout: Upstream server didn't respond in time
üí° Pro Tip: Always document the expected status codes for each endpoint, including both success and error scenarios.

Documenting Error Responses

When documenting errors, include:

  1. Status Code: e.g., 404
  2. Error Message: Human-readable description
  3. Error Code: Machine-readable identifier (optional)
  4. Resolution Steps: How to fix the issue

Example Error Documentation

404 Not Found

The requested video was not found.

Response:
{
  "error": {
    "code": "VIDEO_NOT_FOUND",
    "message": "No video exists with ID abc123",
    "suggestion": "Verify the video ID and try again."
  }
}
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't just say "Error occurred." Provide actionable error messages that help developers debug issues.
üß† Quick Recap:
  • 2xx = Success, 3xx = Redirect, 4xx = Client error, 5xx = Server error
  • Always document expected status codes
  • Provide clear, actionable error messages

examples.title: 200 OK - Successful Response
201 Created - Resource Created
400 Bad Request - Validation Error
401 Unauthorized - Missing Auth
404 Not Found - Resource Missing

quiz.question: Which status code indicates a successful resource creation?
quiz.explanation: 201 Created is the standard status code for successful POST requests that create new resources.

quiz.question: What's the difference between 401 and 403?
quiz.explanation: 401 Unauthorized means you haven't authenticated (missing/invalid credentials). 403 Forbidden means you're authenticated but don't have permission for this resource.

quiz.question: Which status code class indicates server errors?
quiz.explanation: 5xx status codes (500-599) indicate server-side errors.

modules.title: Authentication & Authorization
modules.description: Master API security concepts and learn to document authentication methods.

lessons.title: Authentication vs Authorization
learning_objectives: Differentiate between authentication and authorization
Understand common authentication methods (API Keys, OAuth, JWT)
Document authentication requirements clearly
Write security best practices for API users
lessons.contentHtml:
Authentication vs Authorization

These terms are often confused, but they serve different purposes:

Authentication üîë

"Who are you?"

Authentication verifies the identity of the user or application making the request.

  • Example: Logging in with username/password
  • Example: Providing an API key

Authorization üö™

"What are you allowed to do?"

Authorization determines what resources the authenticated user can access.

  • Example: A user can view their own videos but can't delete another user's videos
  • Example: Admin role has more permissions than regular user role
üí° Pro Tip: Think of authentication as showing your ID at the door, and authorization as having the right ticket for the VIP section.

Common Authentication Methods

1. API Keys üîë

The simplest form of authentication. The client sends a secret key with each request.

Pros:

  • Simple to implement
  • Good for server-to-server communication

Cons:

  • Less secure (key can be stolen)
  • No granular permissions
  • Difficult to revoke for individual users

2. OAuth 2.0 üé´

A standard protocol for authorization, commonly used for third-party access.

Pros:

  • Industry standard
  • Supports scopes (granular permissions)
  • Token-based (can expire and refresh)

Cons:

  • More complex to implement
  • Requires understanding of flows (authorization code, client credentials, etc.)

3. JWT (JSON Web Tokens) üéüÔ∏è

Self-contained tokens that include user information and claims.

Pros:

  • Stateless (server doesn't need to store session data)
  • Can include custom claims
  • Works well with microservices

Cons:

  • Cannot be invalidated before expiry (unless using a blacklist)
  • Larger payload than simple tokens

Documenting Authentication

When documenting authentication, always include:

  1. Method Used: API Key, OAuth, JWT, etc.
  2. How to Obtain: Where users get their credentials
  3. Where to Send: Header name, query parameter, etc.
  4. Format: Exact format required (e.g., "Bearer {token}")
  5. Security Best Practices: Never commit keys to version control, rotate regularly, etc.
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Never include real API keys in documentation examples. Use placeholders like "YOUR_API_KEY" or "sk_test_xxxx".
üß† Quick Recap:
  • Authentication = "Who are you?" | Authorization = "What can you do?"
  • Common methods: API Keys (simple), OAuth (standard), JWT (stateless)
  • Document: method, how to obtain, where to send, format, security tips

examples.title: API Key in Header
examples.code:
curl -X GET 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY'

examples.title: API Key in Python
OAuth 2.0 Access Token
examples.code:
# First, obtain an access token
curl -X POST 'https://api.videodb.io/oauth/token' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  -d 'grant_type=client_credentials' \
  -d 'client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID' \
  -d 'client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET'

# Then use the token in requests
curl -X GET 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN'

quiz.question: What's the difference between authentication and authorization?
choices: Authentication verifies identity, authorization determines permissions
Authentication is for users, authorization is for servers
quiz.explanation: Authentication verifies WHO you are (identity), while authorization determines WHAT you can do (permissions).

quiz.question: Which authentication method is stateless and self-contained?
quiz.explanation: JWT (JSON Web Tokens) are stateless because they contain all the necessary information and don't require server-side session storage.

quiz.question: Should you include real API keys in documentation examples?
quiz.explanation: Never include real API keys in public documentation. Always use placeholders like 'YOUR_API_KEY'.

modules.title: API Reference & OpenAPI Basics
modules.description: Learn to create API reference documentation and master OpenAPI specification.

lessons.title: Introduction to OpenAPI Specification
learning_objectives: Understand the purpose and benefits of OpenAPI
Identify the key components of an OpenAPI document
Write a basic OpenAPI 3.0 specification
Use OpenAPI tools for documentation generation
lessons.contentHtml:
What is OpenAPI?

OpenAPI Specification (formerly Swagger) is a standard, language-agnostic format for describing REST APIs. Think of it as a contract that defines your API's structure.

Why Use OpenAPI?

  • ‚úÖ Auto-generate documentation: Tools like Swagger UI create interactive docs from your spec
  • ‚úÖ Generate client SDKs: Automatically create client libraries in multiple languages
  • ‚úÖ API validation: Ensure requests/responses match the specification
  • ‚úÖ Version control: Track API changes over time
  • ‚úÖ Standardization: Team-wide consistency
üí° Pro Tip: Write your OpenAPI spec BEFORE building the API. It serves as a design document and contract.

OpenAPI Document Structure

An OpenAPI document has three main sections:

1. Info Section

Metadata about your API:

openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: VideoDB API
  version: 1.0.0
  description: API for managing video databases
  contact:
    name: API Support
    email: support@videodb.io

2. Servers

Define where the API is hosted:

servers:
  - url: https://api.videodb.io/v1
    description: Production server
  - url: https://sandbox.videodb.io/v1
    description: Sandbox environment

3. Paths (Endpoints)

The actual API endpoints:

paths:
  /videos:
    get:
      summary: List all videos
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Success

Key Components

ComponentPurpose
pathsDefine API endpoints
componentsReusable schemas, parameters, responses
securityAuthentication methods
tagsGroup related operations
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't confuse OpenAPI 2.0 (Swagger) with OpenAPI 3.0+. The syntax is different. Use OpenAPI 3.0 or higher for new projects.
üß† Quick Recap:
  • OpenAPI = standardized API description format
  • Benefits: auto-docs, client generation, validation
  • Structure: info, servers, paths, components
  • Write the spec first as a design contract

examples.title: Complete OpenAPI 3.0 Example
examples.code:
openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: VideoDB API
  version: 1.0.0
  description: Manage your video database

servers:
  - url: https://api.videodb.io/v1

paths:
  /videos/{videoId}:
    get:
      summary: Get a video by ID
      parameters:
        - name: videoId
          in: path
          required: true
          schema:
            type: string
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Success
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/schemas/Video'
        '404':
          description: Video not found

components:
  schemas:
    Video:
      type: object
      properties:
        id:
          type: string
        title:
          type: string
        duration:
          type: integer
          description: Duration in seconds

examples.title: Security Scheme (API Key)
examples.code:
components:
  securitySchemes:
    ApiKeyAuth:
      type: apiKey
      in: header
      name: Authorization

security:
  - ApiKeyAuth: []

quiz.question: What is the current recommended version of OpenAPI for new projects?
quiz.explanation: OpenAPI 3.0 (or higher) is the current standard. OpenAPI 2.0 was previously called Swagger.

quiz.question: What OpenAPI section defines reusable schemas?
quiz.explanation: The 'components' section contains reusable schemas, parameters, responses, and security schemes.

modules.title: Endpoints, Parameters & Error Handling
modules.description: Master documenting API endpoints, request parameters, and comprehensive error handling.

lessons.title: Documenting API Endpoints
learning_objectives: Structure endpoint documentation effectively
Document path, query, and body parameters
Write clear request and response examples
Create comprehensive parameter descriptions
lessons.contentHtml:
Anatomy of Endpoint Documentation

Every endpoint should include:

  1. üìç Endpoint URL and HTTP method
  2. üìù Description of what it does
  3. üîë Authentication requirements
  4. üìä Parameters (path, query, body)
  5. ‚úÖ Success responses with examples
  6. ‚ùå Error responses with examples
  7. üíª Code examples in multiple languages

Types of Parameters

1. Path Parameters

Part of the URL path itself (required):

GET /videos/{videoId}/comments/{commentId}

Documentation:

  • videoId (string, required): The unique identifier of the video
  • commentId (string, required): The unique identifier of the comment

2. Query Parameters

Appended to the URL after ? (usually optional):

GET /videos?limit=10&sort=created_desc&category=tech

Documentation:

  • limit (integer, optional): Number of results to return (default: 20, max: 100)
  • sort (string, optional): Sort order (options: created_asc, created_desc, title)
  • category (string, optional): Filter by category

3. Body Parameters

Sent in the request body (for POST, PUT, PATCH):

{
  "title": "My Video",
  "description": "A great video",
  "tags": ["education", "tutorial"]
}
üí° Pro Tip: Always specify default values, ranges, and constraints for parameters (e.g., "max length: 255 characters").

Request & Response Examples

Provide complete, realistic examples:

‚úÖ Good Example

curl -X POST 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{
    "title": "My First Video",
    "url": "https://example.com/video.mp4",
    "tags": ["tutorial"]
  }'

‚ùå Bad Example

POST /videos
Send: title, url
Get: video object
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't just say "Returns a video object." Show the actual JSON structure with example values.
üß† Quick Recap:
  • Document 7 things: URL, description, auth, params, success, errors, examples
  • 3 parameter types: path (required), query (optional), body (POST/PUT/PATCH)
  • Always provide complete, realistic examples

examples.title: Full Endpoint Documentation Example
examples.code:
## POST /videos

Create a new video in your collection.

### Authentication
Requires API key in Authorization header.

### Request Body

| Field | Type | Required | Description |
|-------|------|----------|-------------|
| title | string | Yes | Video title (max 255 chars) |
| url | string | Yes | URL of the video file |
| description | string | No | Video description |
| tags | array[string] | No | Tags for categorization |

### Example Request

```bash
curl -X POST 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer sk_test_abc123' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{
    "title": "Product Demo",
    "url": "https://cdn.example.com/demo.mp4",
    "tags": ["demo", "product"]
  }'
```

### Success Response (201 Created)

```json
{
  "id": "vid_xyz789",
  "title": "Product Demo",
  "url": "https://cdn.example.com/demo.mp4",
  "status": "processing",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "tags": ["demo", "product"]
}
```

### Error Responses

**400 Bad Request** - Invalid input
```json
{
  "error": {
    "code": "VALIDATION_ERROR",
    "message": "Title is required"
  }
}
```

**401 Unauthorized** - Missing/invalid API key

quiz.question: Which type of parameter is part of the URL path itself?
quiz.explanation: Path parameters are embedded in the URL path, like /videos/{videoId}.

quiz.question: Should you provide complete, realistic examples in API docs?
quiz.explanation: Yes! Complete examples help developers understand exactly how to use the API.

modules.title: GitBook Integration & Versioning
modules.description: Learn to create beautiful documentation sites with GitBook and manage API versions.

lessons.title: Setting Up GitBook Documentation
learning_objectives: Set up a GitBook documentation space
Organize content with SUMMARY.md
Integrate OpenAPI specifications
Publish and maintain documentation
lessons.contentHtml:
What is GitBook?

GitBook is a modern documentation platform that turns Markdown files into beautiful, searchable documentation websites.

Key Features

  • üìù Markdown-based authoring
  • üîç Full-text search
  • üé® Beautiful, responsive themes
  • üîó Git integration (sync with GitHub)
  • üë• Team collaboration
  • üìä Analytics and insights

GitBook Structure

A typical GitBook project has:

docs/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md          # Homepage
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SUMMARY.md         # Table of contents
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ getting-started/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ installation.md
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ quickstart.md
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ api-reference/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ authentication.md
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ endpoints.md

SUMMARY.md - The Navigation File

This file defines your documentation structure:

# Summary

## Getting Started
* [Introduction](README.md)
* [Installation](getting-started/installation.md)
* [Quick Start](getting-started/quickstart.md)

## API Reference
* [Authentication](api-reference/authentication.md)
* [Endpoints](api-reference/endpoints.md)
  * [Videos](api-reference/videos.md)
  * [Collections](api-reference/collections.md)

## Guides
* [Error Handling](guides/errors.md)
* [Rate Limiting](guides/rate-limits.md)
üí° Pro Tip: Use a logical hierarchy: Introduction ‚Üí Getting Started ‚Üí API Reference ‚Üí Advanced Topics ‚Üí Troubleshooting.

Integrating OpenAPI with GitBook

GitBook can render interactive API docs from OpenAPI specs:

  1. Upload your openapi.yaml file
  2. GitBook automatically generates interactive docs
  3. Users can try API calls directly in the docs

Publishing Your GitBook

  1. Connect GitHub: Link your repository
  2. Auto-sync: Changes pushed to GitHub auto-update GitBook
  3. Custom domain: Use docs.yourcompany.com
  4. Version control: Create separate spaces for different API versions
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't create one giant page. Break content into logical, digestible sections.
üß† Quick Recap:
  • GitBook = beautiful docs from Markdown
  • SUMMARY.md defines navigation
  • Can integrate OpenAPI specs
  • Sync with GitHub for version control

modules.title: Testing Tools & Workflows
modules.description: Master Postman, cURL, YAML validation, and API testing workflows.

lessons.title: API Testing with Postman & cURL
learning_objectives: Use cURL for command-line API testing
Create and organize requests in Postman
Generate code snippets from Postman
Validate API responses
lessons.contentHtml:
Why Test Your API?

Before documenting an endpoint, you must test it to understand:

  • What parameters are actually required
  • What the real response looks like
  • What errors can occur
  • Edge cases and validation rules
üí° Pro Tip: Never document an API endpoint you haven't tested yourself. You'll miss crucial details.

cURL: Command-Line Testing

cURL is a command-line tool for making HTTP requests. It's universal and works everywhere.

Basic cURL Commands

# GET request
curl https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos

# GET with headers
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN" \
  https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos

# POST with JSON data
curl -X POST https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN" \
  -d '{"title":"My Video"}'

# Pretty-print JSON response (with jq)
curl https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos | jq

# Save response to file
curl -o response.json https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos

Postman: Visual API Testing

Postman is a GUI tool for testing APIs. It's perfect for:

  • Organizing requests into collections
  • Saving and reusing requests
  • Auto-generating code snippets
  • Team collaboration
  • Automated testing

Postman Workflow

  1. Create a collection: Group related requests
  2. Add requests: Define method, URL, headers, body
  3. Set environment variables: Store API keys, base URLs
  4. Test: Run requests and inspect responses
  5. Generate code: Export to cURL, Python, JavaScript, etc.
  6. Share: Export collection for team members

Code Generation from Postman

Postman can generate code in 20+ languages:

  1. Create your request in Postman
  2. Click "Code" button ()
  3. Select language (cURL, Python, JavaScript, etc.)
  4. Copy & paste into your documentation
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't forget to remove real API keys before pasting code into documentation!

Best Practices for Testing

  • ‚úÖ Test both success and error scenarios
  • ‚úÖ Try invalid parameters to see error messages
  • ‚úÖ Test edge cases (empty strings, very long values, special characters)
  • ‚úÖ Document the exact request that worked
  • ‚úÖ Save example responses as they appear in reality
üß† Quick Recap:
  • Always test endpoints before documenting
  • cURL = command-line, universal
  • Postman = GUI, great for organization and code generation
  • Test success, errors, and edge cases

lessons.title: Rate Limiting & Pagination
learning_objectives: Explain rate limiting and why it exists
Document rate limit headers and errors
Understand pagination strategies
Document pagination parameters correctly
lessons.contentHtml:
Rate Limiting: Protecting the API

Rate limiting restricts how many requests a client can make in a time period. It prevents abuse and ensures fair resource allocation.

Why Rate Limits Exist

  • üõ°Ô∏è Prevent API abuse and DDoS attacks
  • ‚öñÔ∏è Ensure fair usage across all clients
  • üí∞ Enforce pricing tiers (free vs. paid)
  • üîß Protect server resources

Documenting Rate Limits

Always document:

  1. Limits: How many requests per time period (e.g., 1000 requests/hour)
  2. Headers: Response headers that show remaining quota
  3. Error response: What happens when limit is exceeded (429 status code)
  4. Reset time: When the limit resets

Example Rate Limit Headers

X-RateLimit-Limit: 1000
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 487
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1640000000

429 Too Many Requests Response

{
  "error": {
    "code": "RATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED",
    "message": "Rate limit exceeded. Try again in 42 seconds.",
    "retry_after": 42
  }
}
üí° Pro Tip: Clearly document different rate limits for different endpoints or tiers (free, pro, enterprise).

Pagination: Handling Large Data Sets

Pagination breaks large result sets into smaller "pages" to improve performance and user experience.

Common Pagination Strategies

1. Offset-Based Pagination

Uses limit and offset parameters:

GET /videos?limit=20&offset=40
  • ‚úÖ Simple to implement
  • ‚ùå Performance degrades with large offsets
  • ‚ùå Can miss items if data changes between requests

2. Cursor-Based Pagination

Uses a cursor (pointer) to the next page:

GET /videos?limit=20&cursor=eyJpZCI6MTIzfQ
  • ‚úÖ Consistent results even if data changes
  • ‚úÖ Better performance
  • ‚ùå Can't jump to arbitrary pages

3. Page-Based Pagination

Uses page and per_page parameters:

GET /videos?page=3&per_page=20
  • ‚úÖ Intuitive for users
  • ‚ùå Same issues as offset-based

Pagination Response Format

Include metadata in responses:

{
  "data": [...],
  "pagination": {
    "total": 500,
    "page": 3,
    "per_page": 20,
    "total_pages": 25,
    "next_cursor": "eyJpZCI6ODd9",
    "has_more": true
  }
}
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Don't forget to document the maximum allowed page size (e.g., "max 100 items per page").
üß† Quick Recap:
  • Rate limits protect the API from abuse
  • Document: limits, headers, error response, reset time
  • Pagination strategies: offset, cursor, page-based
  • Include pagination metadata in responses

examples.title: Rate Limit Documentation Example
examples.code:
## Rate Limits

The VideoDB API enforces rate limits to ensure fair usage:

- **Free tier:** 100 requests/hour
- **Pro tier:** 1,000 requests/hour
- **Enterprise:** Custom limits

### Rate Limit Headers

Every response includes these headers:

```
X-RateLimit-Limit: 1000
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 487
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1640000000
```

### When You Hit the Limit

Status: `429 Too Many Requests`

```json
{
  "error": {
    "code": "RATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED",
    "message": "Rate limit exceeded",
    "retry_after": 120
  }
}
```

examples.title: Cursor-Based Pagination Example
examples.code:
# First request
curl 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos?limit=20'

# Response includes next_cursor
{
  "data": [...],
  "next_cursor": "eyJpZCI6MjB9"
}

# Next request uses the cursor
curl 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos?limit=20&cursor=eyJpZCI6MjB9'

quiz.question: What HTTP status code indicates rate limit exceeded?
quiz.explanation: 429 Too Many Requests is the standard status code for rate limit errors.

quiz.question: Which pagination method is best for consistent results when data changes frequently?
quiz.explanation: Cursor-based pagination provides consistent results even when the underlying data changes between requests.

lessons.title: AI-Assisted API Documentation
learning_objectives: Identify use cases for AI in documentation
Use AI to generate initial drafts
Validate and improve AI-generated content
Combine AI efficiency with human expertise
lessons.contentHtml:
The Role of AI in Documentation

AI tools like ChatGPT, Claude, and GitHub Copilot can accelerate documentation writing, but they don't replace human expertise.

What AI Can Help With

  • ‚úÖ Generate initial drafts from code/specs
  • ‚úÖ Create code examples in multiple languages
  • ‚úÖ Suggest descriptions for endpoints
  • ‚úÖ Generate OpenAPI specs from descriptions
  • ‚úÖ Proofread and improve clarity
  • ‚úÖ Translate documentation

What AI Cannot Do Well (Yet)

  • ‚ùå Understand your specific use cases
  • ‚ùå Know your users' pain points
  • ‚ùå Test the API to verify accuracy
  • ‚ùå Maintain consistent voice and style
  • ‚ùå Make strategic documentation decisions
üí° Pro Tip: Use AI for the first draft, then refine with human expertise. The best docs combine AI speed with human insight.

AI Documentation Workflow

  1. Input: Give AI your code, OpenAPI spec, or description
  2. Generate: Ask AI to create documentation drafts
  3. Test: Verify the API works as AI described
  4. Refine: Add context, examples, and user-focused explanations
  5. Review: Ensure accuracy and completeness

Example AI Prompts

Generate OpenAPI Spec

"Create an OpenAPI 3.0 spec for a REST API endpoint that:
- Lists all videos in a collection
- Supports pagination (limit, offset)
- Requires API key authentication
- Returns 200 with array of video objects or 401 if unauthorized"

Generate Code Examples

"Convert this cURL request into Python (using requests library) and JavaScript (using fetch):

curl -X GET 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer API_KEY'"

Improve Clarity

"Make this API description clearer and more user-friendly:

'This endpoint facilitates the retrieval of video resources based on the specified query parameters and authentication credentials provided in the request header.'"
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfall: Never publish AI-generated documentation without testing and verification. AI can hallucinate endpoints, parameters, or behaviors that don't exist.

Tools for AI-Assisted Docs

ToolBest For
ChatGPT / ClaudeDrafting, examples, explanations
GitHub CopilotInline code examples
Mintlify WriterAuto-generate from code
ScribeProcess documentation
üß† Quick Recap:
  • AI accelerates documentation but doesn't replace humans
  • Use AI for: drafts, examples, translations, proofreading
  • Workflow: Generate ‚Üí Test ‚Üí Refine ‚Üí Review
  • Always verify AI output against real API behavior

examples.title: AI Prompt: Generate OpenAPI Spec
examples.code:
Create an OpenAPI 3.0 specification for a POST endpoint:
- URL: /v1/videos
- Creates a new video resource
- Requires: title (string, required), url (string, required), tags (array, optional)
- Returns: 201 with created video object
- Errors: 400 (validation), 401 (auth)
- Uses Bearer token authentication

examples.title: AI Prompt: Improve Description
examples.code:
Make this clearer:

"The endpoint returns a paginated list of video entities with associated metadata and relational data structures."

Target audience: Junior developers new to APIs.

examples.title: AI-Generated Code Examples
examples.code:
# AI can quickly generate examples in multiple languages
import requests

url = 'https://api.videodb.io/v1/videos'
headers = {'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY'}

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
videos = response.json()

for video in videos['data']:
    print(f"Video: {video['title']}")

quiz.question: What is the recommended workflow when using AI for documentation?
quiz.explanation: Always generate with AI, test the output, refine with human expertise, and review for accuracy before publishing.

quiz.question: Should you publish AI-generated docs without testing them?
quiz.explanation: Never! AI can hallucinate features or behaviors. Always test and verify against the real API.
